NOTE: I reported this over 9 months ago to Brookhaven. Never heard any follow up. I have previously reported this to DeKalb Co. and met w/a transpo engineer but nothing happened. We have painted crosswalks from Kaleidoscope across Dresden to the office buildings there - but NO pedestrian crossing signals. It's impossible to cross there safely. We also have crossing issues from Kaleidoscope to Savi (going across Caldwell) - when you "land" at Savi, there is no place to stand to wait to cross to the other side of Dresden. This is particularly dangerous if you have a bike or stroller. In other words, there is NO way to cross Dresden safely at Caldwell - either going over to Savi or trying to cross at the painted crosswalks from Kaleidoscope.The transpo engineer told me the project was approved to add pedestrian crossings and fix the landing space in front of Savi but I don't know if it was funded.
summary: Pedestrian Crossing at Dresden and Caldwell

description: After years of trying to get someone to address the storm drain problems at this location, and getting NO response, I talked with a City of Newnan work crew doing some work nearby.  They called someone to look at this problem and he came right out.  He then called Newnan Utilities to bring their "Camera Snake" out to get a better look.  They found some unusual drain piping and called the City to turn the issue back to them as this was a City problem.  I have never heard from the City.  My Pastor referred me to a Mr. Klahr.  I called him and he said he would get with an engineer and call me to come look at the problem.  After a month with no response, I called Mr. Klahr and left a message to call me back.  It has been a couple of months now and still no response.  I need to know if what Newnan Utilities found with their underground camera and detectors caused my foundation failure as well as the history of foundation problems of my neighbor across the street.
summary: Storm Drain Problems causing Foundations Failures in surrounding homes

From a registered, professional engineer's view point -The traffic light issues on Till Mill Road at Peeler Road and Tilly Mill Road at North Peachtree Road can be directly traced back to the "Diverging Diamond" at Ashford-Dunwood Road and the traffic light at Peachtree-Dunwoody.  Because of the traffic lights on the west bound I-285 exit ramp turning right onto Ashford-Dunwoody, the traffic cannot move as freely as it once did before the "Diverging Diamond".  This slows the traffic on I-285 West back to Peachtree Industrial.  This causes Peachtree Industrial to back up which then causes westbound drivers to bailout onto Tilly Mill Road and Winters Chapel Road.  Drivers on Winters Chapel Road then use Peeler Road which then runs back into Tilly Mill Road.  That is why Peeler and Tilly Mill are now becoming backed up when they did not before the Ashford-Dunwoody "Diverging Diamond".  Also, Perimeter College traffic uses the same Tilly Mill and Winters Chapel Roads along with North Peachtree Road, which just adds to the traffic flow problems.  If you could fix the problems up stream at Peachtree-Dunwood and Ashford-Dunwood, the rest of the system would flow much quicker.It would also help on Tilly Mill Road if the traffic signals were more "intelligent" and could recognize changes in traffic flows on both Tilly Mill and Peeler Road and at Tilly Mill and North Peachtree Roads.Just remember that changes to any system, like adding the Ashford-Dunwood "Diverging Diamond", have consequences - sometimes unintended consequences!
summary: Backup on I-285 West backs up Peachtree Industrial which backs up Tilly Mill Road

It was partially covered by steel plates but half of it was uncovered and you could not see because it was dark. and no lighting in the area. I thought the entire under panel of the car was torn out from the noise I heard. We pulled over into the lot across from CVS andsaw two tires on the right side of my 2009 G6 pontiac were sliced from this huge uncoverd hole or whatever you want to call it.  We had to have the car towed, 2 new tires so far to the tune of $475.00 not counting the tow or the two wheels that need to be replaced as to them being all torn up which are about 350.00 each.  I believe I should be reimbursed from the city as this hole is not covered properly and is a very bad road hazard.
summary: Pothole Not Covered and No lighting around area

The PM traffic is SO bad here that it is actually easier to turn right onto Ashford Dunwoody Road by staying in the left lane and crossing over Ashford Dunwoody, making a u-turn at Ashwoody Trail and then turning left onto Ashford Dunwoody road.In addition when travelling from 285 it is easier to use the Right Turn Only lane to bypass all of the traffic on Ashford Dunwoody, turn right into the office park, make a u turn and then a right turn back onto Ashford Dunwoody road.It happens EVERY afternoon. Apparently they are also planning on adding another Apartment or Condo at this intersection which will only make things worse.
summary: Traffic Backed Up Perimeter Summit Pkwy at Parkside AND Ashford Dunwoody

address: Osborne Road At Peachtree Road Brookhaven, GA
description: During non-peak travel times, it is possible to sit at the intersection of Osborne Road and Peachtree Road for >4 minutes.  Initially, I thought there was a bad loop, but now I've noticed you've got video detection in place; however, it must not be working.   I've been analyzing the situation for several weeks and have discovered that it happens on the mainline as well as the secondary road.   For example, travelling north on Peachtree Road , get in the left turn lane to turn left onto Osborne Road, and you just sit forever or at least until another person comes up behind me.  Is the detector angled incorrectly, maybe so that it doesn't see my little tiny car and only reacts once another vehicle pulls in behind me?  The same behavior occurs on Osborne Road when attempting to turn left (north)onto Peachtree Road.  I thought the detector was broken but it does seem to leap into action if a second vehicle is waiting.  I have not noticed this behavior during peak travel times.

description: There is no crosswalk painted across the turning lane from Peeler Rd to Winters Chapel Rd Eastbound.  There is also no sign alerting motorists that a crosswalk is ahead and this presents a very dangerous situation as motorists cannot see the crosswalk area until they enter the right turn lane at the corner.  Flashing LED lights are need to alert drivers that pedestrians are in the crosswalk and that they must STOP for pedestrians when they are at the edge of or in a crosswalk.  We have had numerous motorists who refuse to yield to pedestrian in the crosswalk.  We've even had motorists cross the double yellow line to go around us when we were in the crosswalk!!We need flashing LED lights on the pedestrian signs and embedded in the roadway along the edges of the crosswalks to capture the attention of motorists who seem oblivious to pedestrians.  The city can purchase these from suppliers such as Traffic Safety Corporation at http://www.xwalk.com/Now that the Walmart Neighborhood Center has opened, it is essential that there are safe walking paths for people to access the newly renovated center.There are also no crosswalks at Glaze Drive or at Four Oaks Drive.  The one at Glaze Drive is needed to provide walking access to the new Autozone store opened on the corner of Peeler Rd. and Winters Chapel Rd.

address: Piedmont Ave Near 10th Northbound Lane Atlanta, Georgia
description: Harry, if you are in the northbound lane of Piedmont Ave, around 10th and farther north (there are several of these from that location, up to Piedmont Park), there are some grates in the road, center of the northbound lane, unnoticable to cars because cars wheels straddle the grate-holes. The street was evidently repaved (maybe several times) and the grates were never raised. They are 2 or 3 inches below street level. No problem for a car, but on a motorcycle following a car, the dang things show up after the car you are following passes over them, too late for a following motorcycle to avoid. They wreck the @#$% out of a motorcycle. Can the city please raise the grates to be at same elevation as the rest of the street by putting some spacers under them, please? I think the depth of the drop hitting these is as much or more than any potholes I've seen on your show. I hope you can get them fixed, and thank you in advance for bringing them to the attention of the city, before they wreck some guy on a motorcycle (motorcycle wheels are usually in the center of the road, unlike car wheels, and hit the things. Potholes happen naturally, we should not engineer them.

When traffic that is heading east on E Crogan St. in downtown Lawrenceville tries to turn left onto Buford Dr. (to head north towards Hwy. 316), they are put in danger of a collision. The left turn only lane should only turn left, but on an almost DAILY basis some traffic continues straight on E Crogan St. This puts traffic in the lane beside the left turn only lane in danger. The lane beside the left turn only lane is a lane that you can either turn left or continue straight. Traffic that chooses to turn left (onto Buford Dr.) may be hit by traffic in the left turn only lane that has continued straight, disregarding the left turn only signs. Please install a barricade to keep left turn only traffic from continuing straight. It must be concrete, because small posts that have been installed have been run over and are no longer there. There is no deterrent. I turn left at this intersection daily and have seen numerous near misses. Thank you!
summary: Need Improvement of Left Turn Lanes

RESIDENT IS REQUESTING A REPLACEMENT GARBAGE CART - CART WAS STOLENDATE:  7-26-2013 (FRIDAY)

July 26, 2013Dear, Pothole PatrolAs a wheel chair bound double amputee, I rely heavily on public transportation (MARTA / MARTA Mobility), to get to and from my doctor(s) appointments and dialysis sessions. It is the latter for which I am seeking your assistance.  Once I disembark from the bus at the intersections of North Avenue and Northside Drive the danger begins. My challenge is the huge holes on both sides of the streets - approximately gaps of 5-6ft in length and the entire width of the sidewalk. Due to the dilapidated sidewalks I am forced into the street and dodge the oncoming traffic which is even more hazardous during the evening rush hours of traffic.I welcome any assistance you can provide to get this matter brought to the attention the appropriate City officials. Not just for me but all others who travel this area also.Thanking you in advance for your consideration and time rendered in this matter.Sincerely,Charlton H. Peyton

Two years ago, the water main in front of our property burst in the middle of December, prompting DeKalb County Public Works to come out. They tore up the end of our driveway in the process of repairing the water main and repaved over it. However, it did not last: at the corner of our driveway, a pothole has grown larger with each month as cars of all sizes, from sedans to 18-wheelers, pass over the pothole at various speeds. As you can imagine, with the traffic that Windsor Parkway sees, the pothole has grown considerably. We called the DeKalb County Public Works Department a year before the formation of the city of Brookhaven, but they have yet to come estimate the damage.I would also like to mention that our neighbor has another larger pothole in front of their property as well.

Several pot holes of considerable size need to be attended.  It appears that someone recently poured a concrete mixture of some sort into some of these places for a 2nd, maybe even a 3rd time, but the end result is an amateur look and obviously, not a permanent fix. These issues can be found at: Ingress/egress drives to the AllStar Trampoline & Tumbling Gymnastics Center, and The Learning Experience Childcare CenterAlso, other pot holes can be found on the un-named (and un- marked) side street that runs off of State Bridge, leading to: The Alpharetta Design Center, 10700 State Bridge Road, and the rear, resident entry of Alara @ Statebridge (now known as Duck Pond @ Johns Creek).I apologize that I am not able to upload an image, because I recently lost my mobile phone.  I would however, appreciate a response to these issues. Again, the substance that someone has used recently and in the past as a temporary solution,  is obviously unsuitable as these troublesome spots always resurface, shortly thereafter.  Turning off of Morton into these places of business or the Alara apartment complex, or onto the unmarked side street at night could lead to vehicle damage and possibly worse, if a vehicle sustains considerable damage or loss.Any assistance you can provide will be appreciated.

Hi, the week of 5/20, and new traffic light was installed at the intersection of Azalea Dr. and Hwy 9.  Going north on Hwy 9, this light is timed to only allow a certain amount of cars turn left onto Azalea, only on a green arrow, then turns red.  Before the change, it was turn left on green arrow, then switched to yield to oncoming traffic after.  This allowed cars to still proceed turning left when it was clear, and keep the flow of traffic moving.  Since the light change, there have been significant traffic build ups going as far back as Hightower Trail and even the Northridge exit.  Does the city plan on alleviating the backups by extending the green turn signal?  Can we revert back to the original light to allow more cars to pass through?  This has been a drastic change in the traffic flow in this area.  Thank you.
summary: New traffic turn signal causing major backups and delays

address: 4795 Peachtree Dunwoody Road Northeast Sandy Springs, GA 30342, USA
description: The traffic light at Peachtree-Dunwoody Road at Windsor Parkway is too short for southbound Peachtree-Dunwoody traffic at the evening rush hour.  Traffic sometimes backs up a mile up to the Glenridge Connector causing grid lock at the light at Glenridge Connector and Peactree-dunwoody.  There are two issues.  First, there is a huge number of cars making a left turn from Peachtree-Dunwoody South-bound on to Windsor parkway East-bound.  The short left turn arrow here causes a large backup of cars at an intersection with a very short left hand turn lane to stack the traffic.  Second, the traffic signal seems to give preference to Windsor parkway traffic which is never as heavy as the traffic on Peachtree-Dunwoody at this time of day. This traffic signal setup needs to be evaluated to allow better flow of the heavy South-bound evening rush hour traffic on this section of Peachtree-Dunwoody. After this intersection, the traffic moves very well.
summary: Signal timing issue causing major backup of traffic

description: A massive erosion hole located on the back of a sewer drain was reported to DeKalb County Roads and Services February 2013.  The county came out and put orange construction fencing around the hole.  Months later they came out and "tv'd" the drain and found an 8ft section of pipe line that has deteriorated, causing the erosion. Since then, no one has come back to fix the pipe and we are continuing to lose earth in our yards.  The erosion has moved to our driveway and it is a dangerous situation.  No one is taking ownership at DeKalb County to fix this dangerous situation.  The hole has tripled in size and our yards have sunk at least 6 inches since we noticed the hole back in February.Our neighbors have a young child and a small dog and this is a danger for their family as well.  Can someone please fix this problem before more damage occurs or God forbid a tragedy happens due to DeKalb County's negligence?

How soon will the street be paved?

When Lenox road goes under NE Expressway and becomes Cheshire bridge, the lanes are mis-painted (not painted at all really). People believe that the turn lane before it goes under the bridge is 2 lanes when it is only one lane. This is because the lane marking paint has worn away. People often try to squeeze two lanes of cars in this wide one lane because they don't know any better. Please have this repainted before someone runs into someone else.
summary: Mis-painted lanes causing issues with traffic

I'm not sure who, if anyone, is responsible for maintaining the "Rehoboth Park". It is completely run down and it had apparently become a hangout place for pot smokers, cigar smokers (I've found cigar butts and wrappers) and public drinking (I've also found mini liquor bottles and beer cans here). Other than the trash the place is not being kept at all. The play sets have spiderwebs, are dirty and have propane and indecent graffiti on them (I abstained from posting the indecent ones here). The playground has overgrown weeds all around and needs the sand to be refreshed. The benches are rotting or have missing boards, the basketball courts don't have hoops and the picnic area is disgusting and is littered with trash.My kids would really to play here but the conditions of this park are simply unacceptable. Is this a Dekalb County park? Who ever maintains this park really needs to step up to the plate.

A patch on the sidewalk along Pangborn Rd., where there's a manhole, is raised a couple inches above the surface of the rest of the sidewalk. This sidewalk has several sections that are uneven but they are not as problematic. You see, since the level difference occurs at an angle in this particular spot, it is very difficult to ride over it with a wheelchair or a stroller. If one is not aware of the "bump" or thinks they may be able to overcome it with some speed it becomes specially dangerous since it WILL stop you in your tracks. I've seen even jogger strollers having to ride over the grass or the road to go around this bump. As mentioned before. This sidewalk has some bad sections but hopefully those will be fixed when the new housing development (opposite Frazier Walk) comes in. However this particular location is not part of the sidewalk that this development would hopefully improve. Please get this fixed.

The entire stretch of Wrights Mill Road between Hwy 372 and Bobo Lane needs to be completely repaved. In the past, someone has come out to fill the potholes at times, but patching it is only a temporary fix and at this point, it feels like an obstacle course and can cause danger to drivers (even at 25 mph). It has HUGE potholes, cracks throughout entire stretch and low hanging trees that need to be trimmed or branches cut. If someone could come out and put this on the books as soon as possible to have this road repaved (and possibly made wider) all of us would appreciate it. It is so bad that it rattles & loosens up the bottoms of our cars when driving and at certain areas only one car can go through at a time (very dangerous going over hilly areas unable to see oncoming traffic). Thank you. your neighbors on Wrights Mill Road, Wrights Mill Way and surrounding areas. If needed, we can take a video to show you a typical day in the life of...
summary: huge potholes, cracks in road, uneven pavement and low hanging trees - Wrights Mill Road (between Hwy 372 and Bobo Lane)

Although there is/was a "no thru trucks" sign at Fischer and 54, semi trucks are using Fischer Rd more and more as a cut thru to I85.  I don't believe there is a sign at Collingsworth and Cannongate, thus semis cut thru and naturally return the same way.  Fischer is a residential street, with houses directly facing the street and there is also a school on this road.  It is also a bicycle route.  As there are no businesses on this road, except a small convenience store, why all the semis?  Gas trucks regularly speed down Fischer on their way to Sams.  Please address this problem and allow us to keep our "country" way of life, the reason most moved out here. Please show us the same respect you showed the Wynn Pond residents.  Thank you

description: If you are traveling south on Johnson Ferry toward Ashford Dunwoody there is a light to merge onto Ashford Dunwoody going south.  Long ago before there was a light you just merged onto Ashford Dunwoody.  Now with the light you must stop and there is no right on red. description: In post office parking

In the last year or so, three popular fast food restaurants have opened in the Northlake mall area, which caused what seems like a 200% increase in traffic, now almost takes 2-3 lights to turn during lunch/evening rush, and with a fourth opening soon, it's only going to get worse. One of the worst things, is that there are no turn signals for the north and south lights at the intersection of Lavista and Henderson Mill. It's gotten so bad, I've watched people turning left (north) onto Lavista from Henderson Mill, actually turn from the straight lane, to get through the light, which causes the traffic coming out of the Northlake Tower Festival (where there is no turn light either) to be put into a dangerous situation. Obviously no one thought to evaluate or improve the traffic conditions when these restaurants were approved. People routinely slam on their brakes to try to get into the shopping center with the restaurants, or block lanes of traffic to get out, since the entryways near the restaurant are in a horrible place. With the increase in traffic, the road markings need to be improved also, the lines are faded, there's no reflective paint on the medians, so you can't see them at night, the turn lanes are only marked with faded arrows on the road, which people can't see now because of all the traffic, so they run the turn lane at shopping center entrances to get to the next one, and for the I-285 entrance on Lavista, there are no overhead signs clearly stating what lanes to be in, so people practically cause accidents to to get in or out of the entrance ramps. The traffic is also causing lots of damage to the roads, as they have started getting pot holes and other damage really quickly. This area needs to be improved quickly, since it seems the number of accidents is rising, or at least the number of cop cars are. At the very least, there need to be turn signals for all the sections at Lavista and Henderson Mill and clearly marked road signs above the road people can see, and better entrances/exits for the Briarcliff Village shopping center and Briarcliff Lavisita Shopping center.

Why is it taking so long to lay one block of sidewalk on the corner of Pleasant Hill Rd and I-85? 7 months ago they dug up a well worn footpath in front of the cemetary on Pleasant Hill Rd. In the meantime they have replaced sidewalks all the way down the road, but this is in my opinion one of the most dangerous intersections for pedestrians and cyclists to cross on Pleasant Hill Rd. and they expect us to cross it twice in one block. There is no sidewalk in front of Best Buy across the street, then the sidewalk on the bridge on that side of the road is blocked by concrete barriers, forcing pedestrians to cross where cars are turning right on Pleasant Hill and across the street cars are turning right onto I-85 north. These people do not stop for pedestrians or cyclists. Set up a camera and you will see a pedestrian in the crosswalk waiting for car after car to pass while standing in the crosswalk with a walk sign. The construction company building this sidewalk is obviously in no hurry. They work one or two days a week if that, and 7 months later, I still risk my life every day crossing an intersection I would never cross if I had a choice. But I have to do this commute every day either by bicycle or on foot when it rains. And there are many other pedestrians and cyclists that need this stretch of sidewalk completed. I don't know whose idea it was to build a stone wall and put brick masonry on the sidewalks in addition to concrete, but they have wasted a ton of tax payer money when all we needed was a sidewalk in a timely fashion. Please, someone light a fire under their butts.
summary: 7 months and counting  to complete 1 block of sidewalk

Due to the high volume of heavily loaded trucks, the pavement on Pleasantdale Road between Lake Drive and i-85 is in desperate need of repair.  In addition to the Nordic Refrigerated Storage facility, the Usher Tanker Transport company and the Metro Green industrial recycling center, (approved by your traffic engineer), have opened within the last year.  As of today, there are least 6 potholes within this _ mile.  The railroad crossing at Pleasantdale and Oakdale has been in disrepair for several years.  Traffic has been merging left to get around the rough crossing in the right lane.  We don't need another quick patch on the crumbling asphalt; we need a complete and thorough repair of this entire stretch of road.

I have previously reported this to DeKalb Co. and met w/a transpo engineer but nothing happened. We have painted crosswalks from Kaleidoscope across Dresden to the office buildings there - but NO pedestrian crossing signals. It's impossible to cross there safely. We also have crossing issues from Kaleidoscope to Savi (going across Caldwell) - when you "land" at Savi, there is no place to stand to wait to cross to the other side of Dresden. This is particularly dangerous if you have a bike or stroller. In other words, there is NO way to cross Dresden safely at Caldwell - either going over to Savi or trying to cross at the painted crosswalks from Kaleidoscope. The transpo engineer told me the project was approved to add pedestrian crossings and fix the landing space in front of Savi but I don't know if it was funded.

address: 1342-1350 N Morningside Dr Ne Atlanta, GA
description: Issue ID:  266092 Viewed:  3 times Neighborhood:  Atlanta Watershed RegionReported via: http://www.cbsatlanta.comReported: about 1 hour agoTagged: traffic, signs, pothole.DescriptionThe new curbing on the southwest corner of N Morningside and North Highland Ave blocks what used to be a right turn lane. Traffic now backs up single file on N Morningside because vehicles can no longer turn right on red if there is any vehicle stopped at the light. The curb seems to serve no useful purpose except to trick drivers into thinking there is a right turn lane, then immediately "dead ending" into a solid curb where a right turn lane would normally be!Who designs these curbs, anyway? Rip it up, send the DOT roadway designers to "curb school" and try again. Not only is this a terrible design which restricts traffic flow for no good reason, but I believe it is only a matter of time before someone wrecks their car by driving right over this new senseless "dead-end" lane.(Reposted to this watch area for better reporting and tracking)
summary: New Curbing at N Morningside & N Highland not helping pedestrians & making hazard for drivers.

People in wheelchairs are not able to move from sidewalk to street without extreme effort on the Baraonda restaurant side of the street, heading to the Fox. I watched 2 different incidents before an event at the Fox Theatre on 10/3. A man trying to push a woman from sidewalk to street could not get her onto the road, even with help. He finally turned her chair around and was able to pull. A mother was pushing her young son in his wheelchair when he was almost tossed forward when she hit the large uneven bump. What was interesting, is that in both scenario's the people just smiled and moved on.  They have good hearts; however, I truely believe people with physical issues and their caretakers should not be burdened with such inconveniences. I am sure this city and hundreds of others have many obsticles like this for the physically impared, but it is something I observed first hand and I was affected by it.  With it being so close to the Fox, I'm sure it happens all the time. Thank you, Katrina Avey

Problem:    There is no side walk from the bridge up until the spring gate subdivision (approximately 700 feet). At this point the side walk begins on the other side of the road.    Due to the lack of sidewalk, there are many adults and children alike are crossing the 700 feet pass by either walking on the road itself or by walking 2-3 inches away from the road. This is incredibly dangerous for the pedestrian as well as the drivers on Rucker St. I along with many drivers have had to swerve at 35mph after seeing a pedestrian precariously crossing this area only a few inches from the road. Pedestrians wanting to simply enjoy a morning or evening walk place themselves in mortal peril by crossing this pass. By creating a break in sidewalk, we have in essence segregated the two communities living on either side and significantly discouraged them from walking towards the other side.Simple Solution: Connect the existing side walk from before the bridge with the existing sidewalk 200 feet past Harris road. By connecting the two, you will ensure that drivers and pedestrians can coexist safely AND that pedestrians will not have to cross the road after the bridge and jaywalk unnecessarily.
summary: No Sidewalk  Pedestrians Crossing and Cars Swerving  - Dangerous!

On the south side of the intersection, northbound traffic's left lane has a straight or left arrow painted on the roadway. The right lane has a straight-only arrow.  The confusion lies in what is considered "straight" for the left and right lanes.  Right lane traffic physically points toward the exit (confusingly called East Lake Dr also) to W College Ave.  Left lane traffic physically points towards the right lane of East Lake Dr that is located on the north side of the intersection.  Because there are no painted guidelines through the intersection, confusion can occur as northbound traffic in the "right straight" lane on the south side of the intersection divert to the right lane of East Lake Dr in the middle of the intersection, causing the potential for a collision with traffic in the "left straight" lane on the south side of the intersection who are targeting for the same right lane on East Lake Dr. A painted guideline through this intersection would eliminate confusion regarding lane ownership.
summary: NB East Lake Dr Traffic Needs Lane Clarification

.The road material between the tracks is formed like a speed breaker.  If a vehicle crosses at the speed limit the driver can lose control.  There are east and westbound tractor trailer skid marks from this happening.  In addition to normal traffic, more than 1000 vehicles a day from Twiggs, Wilkinson, Laurens, Bleckley and Dodge Counties travel to Robins AFB . This crossingt does not meet the standards of DOT.  The Twiggs County Commission, State Representative Bubber Epps, DOT and Norfolk Southern have been contacted several times since May 15, 2012.  DOT did have the new blacktop milled down which has helped some.  However Norfolk Southern need to repair the crossing.  If they need examples of how it should be look at Booth Rd or Watson Blvd crossings in Warner Robins. This crossing needs to be fixed before there is an acident with injuries or death.

address: 3614 N Druid Hills Road Decatur, GA
description: This morning around 7:30am as I was trying to drive to my job I was stopped at the exit of my neighborhood by a fire truck with lights flashing and 2 Dekalb County officers directing traffic. A car belonging to a new neighbor who lives on N. Druid Hills Road (3614 NDH Road) had been t-boned by a speeding driver.  It was completely totaled with all airbags deployed.  It was crumpled at the entrance of her driveway - she almost made it.  Thank God she was not injured.  Had she had a passenger or a child in the car, the same would not be said.I am a resident of N. Druid Valley off N. Druid Hills Road and we need your help with a traffic problem that has taken enough of a toll on us and our neighbors.  Less than 10 days ago, there was a fatal wreck near the exact same spot.  In 1976, a little boy was killed crossing the road to get to school.  The issue is that the speed of this road and the lack of traffic calming or electronic signals is taking its toll on us - the 110 homes in my neighborhood, along with the homes that line N. Druid Hills and the hundreds of homes in the area.To document crashes, injuries, and deaths, my volunteer neighborhood association, North Druid Valley Home Association has put together a website: http://www.northdruidkills.com This website is going to be used to continuously compile the dangers of this stretch of road that is handling too much traffic.  We plan on using it to raise the volume of our voice to get some help.  We hope you are listening.We are subject to the dangers of those speeding off 78 onto what should not be an extension of the highway - North Druid Hills is like a racetrack during the morning and evening commute.  It is a danger to exit our neighborhood at N. Valley Road and N. Druid Circle - we are completely cut off from an intersection with a stop light.  And we are in between a raceway used by folks who speed to and from work daily.  If we are not at risk of being hit coming out, then we are by turning in. Many of the photos on the website show rear-end collisions.Sincerely yours,Patrick S.Decatur, GA 30033Read the growing list of stories and the increasing number of photos here:http://www.northdruidkills.com

We have a very frustrating situation in our neighborhood. It is a townhome community and the concrete streets between the buildings are city owned. They are in horrible condition due to a botched water line replacement by the county several years ago. The city knows that this is a problem but they insist that the only way they will fix them is if the HOA takes deed of the streets after being replaced. That would require approval from the majority of the owners which is very unlikely to pass, so we are stuck with crumbling streets.  There are more details if you are interested in taking this on.- Adam Beck Woodehaven POA President.

address: 1697-1723 Northwest Dr Nw Atlanta, GA 30318, USA
description: Northwest Drive from Bolton Rd to James Jackson Parkway is uncomfortable, uneven and needs to be paved. There are serious holes in the street and I personally feel as if though I'm playing Mario Cart every time I'm going & coming home. It's quit annoying and it a horrible start and ending to one's workday or outing. This community needs for that stretch if road to be PAVED; not patched!! As has been the resolve with the bridge that covers Proctor Creek.Every so often, there's a metal plate that covers a whole. The City of Atlanta allows the contractors to not to complete the project and it stays there for several months. Last week a crew arrived to do another one of its patchwork projects. Furthermore, I think the City of Atlanta needs to do a better job monitoring these contractors and employees. For example, doesn't Public Works do a drive by and go seek out projects to complete in order to create a better environment in this great city?I know there are people who hold care about their jobs and may be over-worked but the negligence going in various departments is increasing and being reflected in the lack of proper management and infrastructure. In closing, please fix the streets in this community; starting with Northwest Drive.

At the corner of Browns Mill rd (GA 212) and Salem Road the street is crumbling at the edge and the mud is overtaking the pavement.  Many travelers use Salem rd to access GA 212 and make a left or right.  Because GA 212 can be so busy many travelers accelerate to merge to the right into the gaps of traffic however I'm noticing that lately the mud is limiting their traction. There is a dangerous street that has no sidewalk. My mother is an amputee and uses a wheelchair. When she wants to go to the store, she rides in the street because there is not a sidewalk on my side of the street. The police has talk us that she can't ride there because it is dangerous. Well we have tried to get a sidelwalk in place there, but the city says the county is responsible and the county says the city. There have been people killed because there is not a sidewalk there. The strip is along a curve. There are sidewalks every where, except the area in front of my house and that strip. Can you please help me get some type of action? I am not attempting to get a petition started and I want to speak with the Mayor of Hampton, Ga to find out what can be done. This is a serious safety issue. Thanks in advance for any assistance.

address: Sylvan Rd At Murphy Ave And Lee Street Atlanta, GA
description: Can someone please repave the entire intersection of Sylvan, Murphy, and the part across the RR Tracks where it meets Lee Street? You feel like youre driving over a gravel road hitting potholes along the way. The part where it meets lee street looks like the street melted and made ribs in the road as the asphalt slid down the hill. Its like the ribbing they add along highways to wake you up if you start to sway off the highway except much worse becuase you are slowing down as you come off the tracks and it amplifies the effect. The intersection of murphy and sylvan absolutely needs a complete redo. IMHO all of sylvan road needs to be redone but staying on topic, the RR tracks dont meet the road, you literally have to drive like you are out in the country on a gravel road even though you are in the middle of a very busy intersection in atlanta while getting a lovely view of a probation office.

Ever since pitch of road was changed, water flows over the sidewalk and down the hill into Perkerson Park. Its creating a huge ravine. The drain there is clogged but even when its not clogged, it still pours over the side of the hill becuase the low point of the road comes before the drain. The problem was caused by changing the pitch of the road when they did the new sewer lines. They need to raise the sidewalk or extend the flowover apron out further. And they need to clean out the drain. But this gets clogged within a month after unclogging. 1 drain to serve all that water coming down the hill is not enough and is always clogged becuase street sweepers never come by and the drain itself is just too small for all the debris that comes down the hill

Everyone knows the S.W. section of Atlanta is often forgotten. However, there is a dire need for a traffic light and crosswalk at Campbellton Road at the entrance of the Cascade Glen Apartments before a driver or pedestrian gets killed. This location needs a crosswalk and light for several combined reasons.First, this is a large complex that houses a large group of citizens who rely on MARTA to get to and from. School buses also enter the complex to pick up students from several nearby schools. There is also a MARTA stop just outside the entrance on both sides of the street, but no crosswalk for pedestrians to get across to the East bound buses. Pedestrians find themselves caught in the motorist turn lanes trying to get across to the other side. More importantly, there is a blind curve that obstructs the vision of people driving out of the complex and the apartment marquis also blocks the vision of drivers trying to enter Campbellton Road. Once you have pulled out onto Campbellton Road, it's like playing Russian Roulette with the oncoming traffic you can't see until it's right up on you. Moreover, speeding cars coming around this blind spot and on the opposite side of the street have  led Atlanta police officers to frequently set up speed traps right here at the trouble area, instead of putting up a stop light to control the flow of traffic. What is needed is a crosswalk and traffic light on Campbellton Road and facing the traffic coming out of the complex to control the flow of traffic just West of Fairburn Rd. and allowing for the complex's traffic to enter the roadway with the threat of being struck with traffic coming around this blind spot. It's a "no-brainer" once you see the situation. And this would allow citizens to cross safely to the bus stop on the Eastbound side and allow drivers a safer way of getting onto Campbellton Road. If a crosswalk and light is installed, it should be noted that the Westbound MARTA bus stop should be moved back to the complex's entrance instead of the way it is now situated in between the complex's entrance opening and the exit opening. Please help before you end up coming out here to cover a tragedy!
summary: Help us get a light and crosswalk before a tragedy happens!

Harry:Though this isn't about 'potholes' it is about bed bug infestations and cockroach overruns at a local extended stay hotel...we all pay hard earned money for our place...and even though most of us are pretty good about keeping our small extended stay homes as clean as possible...the owners and management do "NOTHING" to replace bug infested mattresses or mattresses with excessive bloody and seminal fluids on them thus causing a huge problem with bugs for the beds AS WELL AS THE FACT that the only time they exterminate is ONLY WHEN SOMEONE who has been here for an extended period of time leaves or is evicted and then they use local OTC products and then they run into our homes...ISN'T THERE ANYTHING THAT CAN BE DONE TO MAKE THIS PLACE CLEANER AND SAFER TO STAY AND LIVE...this place I refer to is THE METRO LODGE HOTEL located at 4975 Canton Highway in Marietta, GA  30066...most of us are here because of lost jobs and or second incomes and no place else to go, but we pay on time and every week...isn't there someone who can make these owners more compliant and cleaner...???? Help!!!!!  To date, I myself have spent over a $100 in trying to get rid of these bugs and I really can't afford it...but someone needs to get on this.  Also...I would like to remain anonymous if at all possible..Many thanks.

address: Corner Of Turner Hill Road (Sr 124) At Stonecrest Mall Pkwy LITHONIA, GA
description: I am an older woman and this is a dangerous intersection for us who can't run fast. After 9am, during the week, I get off MARTA bus 116 at the corner, on right side of Turner Hill Rd at Mall Parkway.  Once I cross over Mall Pkwy to get on the side where I need to cross over Turner Hill Rd to get to RiteAid, I press the light many times for it to change and it never does. (I work down the hill in the Strayer Univ. bldg and that is the only section of Turner Hill at Mall Pkwy that allows you to cross with a Crosswalk light).  However, no matter how many times you press for walk, it doesn't change.  Tuesday. Sept 27 was my first time crossing there. I waited 5 or more minutes without it turning.  I finally took a chance and crossed against the light that day and each day thereafter.  This is bad if the weather gets bad because drivers may not see pedestrians crossing.  I pray you can get this fixed soon.  Thank you very much for all you do.Cynthia Huffman

The two times in seven years I've seen them fixed, they were broken again within weeks, and it took years to have them repaired again.  We need a PERMANENT fix for this road which sees tens of thousands of cars, trucks and buses across is monthly.

I live on a corner street that rain drains into our ditch for at least 2 blocks maybe even 4. Anytime it rains especially hard I end up with a moat. I have asked the city of Perry to maintain it because the ditch is dug out too deep and over the years when asked to fix the ditch they just kept digging it deeper. The drainage became so stagnant that in June 2009 an oak tree that had been on the property since at least 50 years fell over luckily hitting no one or nothing except the road. At the time, my mother spoke with city works supervisor and they advised her to engineer a plan to allow for a covered drainage system and present it at a council meeting. Problem - no engineering experience especially with drainage systems so since the tree fell it is now eroding my neighbors yard as well. The covered drainage system would allow easier maintenance of the ditch, safety of people and animals from falling in the deep ditch, speed water flow to the drainage system, remove the eye sore that has been here for years, stop my neighbors yards from having smalls lakes in their yards when it rains and no longer will I have to watch my yard turn into a flood zone because of the moats that are created by poor condition of the drainage in the ditches.

address: Freedom Park Trail Atlanta, GA 30312, USA
description: The pedestrian signal for the Freedom Park PATH at Boulevard is not functioning properly. All other pedestrian signals at this intersection change automatically with the traffic signal, but the east/west signal at the southern end of the intersection (controlling bike/pedestrian traffic on the PATH) does not. Further, there are no loop detectors embedded in the pavement to detect bicycles. If arriving at the intersection on a green light, cyclists must either proceed against the "Don't Walk" signal, or must press the pedestrian signal button and wait for a full cycle (4-5 minutes) before receiving a "Walk" signal.
summary: East/West PATH Pedestrian Signal Not Functioning Properly

Coming from I-75 on Shallowford Road, there is a drop off at the corner at the intersection of Shallowford Road and Jenkins Road. The drop off causes cars making a right turn from Shallowford to swing too close into stopped oncoming cars making a left turn from Jenkins Road. Accidents occurring at this spot would significantly back up traffic on Shallowford Road, possibly to Gunbarrel Road. The drop off is also rough on vehicles. It violently jerks the car and passengers downward and could cause serious harm to fragile people, small children and infants. The drop off needs to be filled before a serious problem occurs.

Traffic backs up on GA-21 south in the morning back beyond the GA-21/GA-30 intersection.  If the South I-95 exit ramp gets a no through-traffic sign (so you can't get off I-95, go straight back through the intersection and onto I-95 again) then a right turn light could be added for the right lane of south GA-21 to get onto I-95 south, adding to the length of the green light.  Additionally, if the onramp is split to 2 lanes (it's wide enough) a protected right turn lane could be added, removing the red light all together to keep traffic moving (traffic from GA-21 north and south would merge on the ramp before merging on I-95).

The intersections at Skidaway-LaRoach, Skidaway-DeRenne, and Skidaway and Bonna Bella Drive warrant repaving. As this length of road exist, it is unsafe and is a hazzard to vehicle traffic as cars drive into the opposite lanes to avoid damaged areas over the length of Skidaway and 52nd street through Skidaway and Bonna Bella Drive. description: Since the area of Pooler has began to grow with more and more construction which include houses, apartments complex's, stores, distribution areas the junction @ Hwy 80 and Pine Barren road has grown increasingly unsafe. Not only is it unsafe but the population coming in and out of this area is growing fast which has caused some major delays. I live on Pine Barren ans witness all the troublesome issues but it seems like no one else is attempting to fix a very simple, much needed problem. Not to mention the accidents that are caused by drivers who have waited and are very agitated that assume it's okay to drive out in traffic would be lessened if there was some action taken to reduce the problem.The junction @ Hwy 80 and Pine Barren seems to have become a "shortcut" for people to get to Pooler Pkway or other areas which has gotten extremely worse over the last 5 years. Thank you
